meta.title: AV Script Format and Scripting Structures

summary: A/V (Audio-Visual) script format separates auditory information from visual directives, forcing writer to visualize video before filming. This reveals visual gaps and ensures dynamic editing potential throughout content.

core_principles.description: Audio on left (voiceover, dialogue), Visuals on right (B-roll, graphics, camera moves). Separation forces visualization and prevents 'talking head' fatigue.
AV format makes visual gaps obvious - sections where audio continues without visual change. These gaps must be filled with B-roll, graphics, or camera moves.
Punctuation and spacing in script provide natural cutting points and pacing guides for editor. Commas, ellipses, bold text indicate delivery nuances.
Script must explicitly call for kinetic typography, data visualization, overlays. 'Text on screen: [text] animates in sync with word' format.
Plan B-roll injection to synchronize visuals with spoken words. Visual rhythm should match verbal rhythm through careful script timing.

techniques.name: A/V Two-Column Table Format
techniques.description: Industry-standard format with Audio column (left) and Visual column (right). Forces visualization and visual gap detection.
implementation: Left column: Voiceover, dialogue, sound cues
Right column: Camera shots, B-roll, graphics, text
Synchronize timing - visual aligns with audio
examples: Left: 'The best way to learn coding is through practice...' | Right: Close-up on computer screen, fingers typing
Left: 'Here are the three steps...' | Right: Text overlay 'Step 1', 'Step 2', 'Step 3' appears
Left: 'When I first started...' | Right: Match cut to old photo/video archive
pros_cons: More time to write than prose

techniques.name: B-Roll Injection Specification
techniques.description: Replace vague B-roll instructions with specific, detailed shot descriptions that sync with spoken content.
implementation: Use: 'B-roll: Low angle shot of boots hitting mud, rapid cut to drone shot of summit'
Match visual action to spoken timing
examples: 'Speaker mentions boiling water' → 'Close-up: Water reaches rolling boil, steam rising'
'Explains screen recording' → 'B-roll: Actual screen recording showing the process'
'Describes hiking trail' → 'Medium shot: Trail winding through forest, then aerial: Mountain view'
'Talks about tools' → 'Specific shots: Each named tool clearly shown with label overlay'
pros_cons: Requires production planning and B-roll access

techniques.name: Motion Design Prompt Integration
techniques.description: Script explicitly calls for kinetic typography and data visualization with timing specifications.
implementation: Use format: 'Text on screen: [content] animates in sync with word'
techniques.timing: As content is spoken in script
examples: 'Text on screen: \"50% Retention\" animates in sync with word \"retention\"'
'Chart appears: Bar graph showing retention percentages as discussed'
'Counter appears: Numbers count up as statistics are announced'
'Title overlay: \"Mistake #1\" pops in with shake effect'
pros_cons: Editor has clear motion design instructions
Requires motion graphics skills or templates

techniques.name: Pacing Notes through Punctuation
techniques.description: Use punctuation and formatting in script to indicate delivery pacing, natural cuts, and editorial rhythm.
implementation: Bold text: Emphasis, volume increase, energy spike
examples: 'This one setting... actually fixed the audio completely.' (ellipses = dramatic pause)
'The three steps are: step 1, step 2, and step 3.' (commas = list pacing)
'When I first started... I made every mistake in the book.' (dramatic pause)
pros_cons: Provides natural cutting points for editor

techniques.name: Shot Notation and Camera Direction
techniques.description: Include technical shot notation in visual column to guide cinematography and editing decisions.
implementation: Use shot notation: WS (Wide Shot), MCU (Medium Close-up), CU (Close-up)
Include camera moves: PAN, TILT, DOLLY, ZOOM
Note transitions: MATCH CUT, CUT ON ACTION
examples: 'Speaker explains' → 'MCU shot, camera pushes in slightly as importance increases'
'Big reveal' → 'Slow ZOOM IN on product, hold for emphasis'
'Transition to B-roll' → 'PAN right from face to start of B-roll sequence'
'Emotional moment' → 'CU on eyes, slow push in'
pros_cons: Guides camera work and editing simultaneously

script_format_comparison.description: Dialogue written in paragraphs with minimal visual notes
script_format_comparison.retention_advantage: Low - leads to talking head fatigue

script_format_comparison.description: Audio on left, detailed visuals on right
Narrative blocks with interspersed visual tags

gap_indicators: No B-roll specified for spoken content
